types.name: Admin
types.description:
An administrator profile in the KpPay system.

Administrators have elevated privileges to manage the platform,
including user management, merchant approval, and system configuration.

Status values:
- "active": Admin has full access to their permissions
- "inactive": Admin access is temporarily disabled
- "suspended": Admin access has been suspended

fields.name: email
fields.description: Admin's email address (used for communication and login)

fields.name: firstName
fields.description: Admin's first/given name

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the admin

fields.name: insertedAt
fields.description: Timestamp when the admin was created

fields.name: lastName
fields.description: Admin's last/family name

fields.name: phone
fields.description: Admin's contact phone number

fields.name: role
fields.description: Role of the admin (typically 'admin')

fields.name: status
fields.description: Current status of the admin account (active, inactive, suspended)

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description: Timestamp when the admin was last updated

types.name: String
types.description: The `String` scalar type represents textual data, represented as UTF-8 character sequences. The String type is most often used by GraphQL to represent free-form human-readable text.

types.name: ID
types.description: The `ID` scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable. When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"4"`) or integer (such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.

types.name: AdminDashboardStats
types.description: Provides aggregated statistics for the admin dashboard.

types.name: Int
types.description: The `Int` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. Int can represent values between -(2^31) and 2^31 - 1.

types.name: AdminFilters
types.description: Fields available for filtering admins.

inputFields.name: password
inputFields.description: Password (min 8 chars, must include uppercase, lowercase, and number)

fields.name: pageSize
fields.description: The number of items per page.

fields.name: totalEntries

fields.name: totalPages

inputFields.name: precision
inputFields.description: Number of decimal places for the currency. Defaults to 2 if not provided.

inputFields.name: symbol

types.name: Date
types.description:
The `Date` scalar type represents a date. The Date appears in a JSON
response as an ISO8601 formatted string, without a time component.

types.name: DateTime
types.description:
The `DateTime` scalar type represents a date and time in the UTC
timezone. The DateTime appears in a JSON response as an ISO8601 formatted
string, including UTC timezone ("Z"). The parsed date and time string will
be converted to UTC if there is an offset.

types.name: Decimal
types.description:
The `Decimal` scalar type represents signed double-precision fractional
values parsed by the `Decimal` library. The Decimal appears in a JSON
response as a string to preserve precision.

inputFields.description: Customer phone number (for mobile money supported_providers)

types.name: LoginInput
types.description:
Input for user authentication.

## Fields
- `email_or_phone`: Email address or phone number registered with the account
- `password`: Account password (case-sensitive)

## Authentication Process
1. The system first tries to match the provided email/phone to a user account
2. If found, the password is validated against the stored hash
3. On successful validation, a session token is generated and returned

## Security Notes
- Failed login attempts are rate-limited to prevent brute force attacks
- After 5 consecutive failed attempts, the account may be temporarily locked
- Password complexity requirements: minimum 8 characters, mixed case, numbers/symbols

## Example Usage
```graphql
mutation {
  login(input: {
    email_or_phone: "user@example.com",  # Can also use phone number
    password: "SecurePassword123"
  }) {
    token
    userAccount {
      id
      role
    }
  }
}
```

inputFields.name: emailOrPhone
inputFields.description: Email address or phone number associated with the account

inputFields.name: password
inputFields.description: Password for the account (minimum 8 characters, case-sensitive)

types.name: LogoutResult
types.description:
Return type for logout operation.

Indicates whether the logout was successful and provides a status message.

fields.name: message
fields.description: Status message about the logout operation

fields.name: success
fields.description: Whether the logout operation was successful

types.name: Merchant
types.description:
A merchant profile in the KpPay system.

Merchants represent business entities that can process payments, receive funds,
and manage their business information within the platform.

Status values:
- "active": Merchant is fully operational
- "pending": Merchant is awaiting approval
- "suspended": Merchant operations are temporarily suspended
- "inactive": Merchant is not currently active
- "rejected": Merchant application was rejected

Business types:
- "retail": Physical retail businesses
- "e-commerce": Online businesses
- "service": Service-based businesses
- "food": Restaurants and food services
- "travel": Travel and hospitality businesses

fields.name: businessDescription
fields.description: Detailed description of the business

fields.name: businessName
fields.description: Legal or trading name of the business

fields.name: businessType
fields.description: Type of business (retail, e-commerce, service, etc.)

fields.name: businessWebsite
fields.description: URL to the merchant's website

fields.name: country
fields.description: Country where the merchant is located

fields.name: email
fields.description: Primary contact email for the business

fields.name: group
fields.description: Optional grouping category for the merchant

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the merchant

fields.name: insertedAt
fields.description: Timestamp when the merchant was created

fields.name: logoUrl
fields.description: URL to the merchant's logo image

fields.name: phone
fields.description: Contact phone number for the business

fields.name: status
fields.description: Current status of the merchant account (active, pending, suspended, etc.)

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description: Timestamp when the merchant was last updated

types.description: Fields available for filtering merchants.

inputFields.description: Filter by the type of business.

inputFields.name: country

types.name: MerchantInput
types.description:
Input for creating a new merchant account.

All required fields must be provided to ensure complete business information.
Email must be unique in the system and will be used for login.
Password must meet security requirements and match the confirmation.

Business types accepted:
- "retail": Physical retail businesses
- "e-commerce": Online businesses
- "service": Service-based businesses
- "food": Restaurants and food services
- "travel": Travel and hospitality businesses

inputFields.name: businessName
inputFields.description: Legal or trading name of the business

inputFields.name: businessType
inputFields.description: Type of business (retail, e-commerce, service, food, travel)

inputFields.name: country
inputFields.description: Country where the merchant is located

inputFields.name: group
inputFields.description: Optional grouping category for the merchant

inputFields.name: logoUrl
inputFields.description: URL to the merchant's logo image

inputFields.name: merchantRejectionReason
inputFields.description: Only used internally if merchant is rejected

inputFields.description: Password (min 8 chars, must include uppercase, lowercase, and number)

types.description: Input for initiating a transfer via MTN MoMo. Requires wallet ID, amount, currency code, customer phone, and optional description.

fields.name: changePassword
fields.description:
Change the password for a user, merchant, or admin account.

Requirements:
- Must provide the current password for verification
- Password can only be changed once every three months (admin users exempt)
- New password must meet complexity requirements (minimum 6 characters, at least one lowercase,
  one uppercase, and one digit or special character)

Returns success status and updated user account if successful, or appropriate error message.

If attempting to change password before the three-month period has elapsed, the error message
will indicate how many days remain until the password can be changed again.

Example:
```graphql
mutation {
  changePassword(input: {
    oldPassword: "OldPass123",
    newPassword: "NewPass456",
    newPasswordConfirmation: "NewPass456"
  }) {
    success
    message
    userAccount { id email }
    errors
  }
}
```

fields.name: createBankInfo
createContactDetail
createCurrency
fields.description:
Create a new currency.

This mutation allows the creation of a new currency in the system.

Example:
```graphql
mutation {
  createCurrency(input: { code: "EUR", name: "Euro", symbol: "", precision: 2, exchangeRateUsd: 1.2, countryCode: "DE", isActive: true, countryNames: ["Germany", "Austria"] }) {
    id
    code
    name
    symbol
    precision
    exchangeRateUsd
    countryCode
    isActive
    countryNames
    insertedAt
  }
}
```

refreshToken
fields.description:
Refresh an expired authentication token using a valid refresh token.

Use this mutation when the access token has expired but the refresh token is still valid.
This allows the client to obtain a new access token without requiring the user to re-authenticate.

## Process
1. Client detects an expired access token (401 Unauthorized response)
2. Client calls this mutation with the refresh token
3. If valid, a new access token is issued
4. Client updates its stored token and continues making API calls

## Error Handling
- If the refresh token is invalid or expired, the client must redirect to login
- If the user's account status has changed (suspended, deactivated), token refresh will fail

## Example Usage
```graphql
mutation {
  refreshToken(token: "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...") {
    accessToken
    refreshToken
  }
}
```

## Security Notes
- Refresh tokens are long-lived and should be stored securely
- If a refresh token is compromised, all user sessions should be invalidated
- For high-security applications, consider using one-time refresh tokens

args.name: token
args.description: The refresh token to use for obtaining a new access token

fields.name: registerAdmin
registerMerchant
fields.description:
Register a new merchant account.

Creates a new merchant account with the provided business information.
The email address must be unique in the system.
Merchant accounts typically start with "pending" status until approved by an admin.

Example:
```graphql
mutation {
  registerMerchant(input: {
    businessName: "Example Store",
    email: "contact@examplestore.com",
    phone: "1234567890",
    businessType: "retail",
    businessWebsite: "https://examplestore.com",
    businessDescription: "A retail store selling example products",
    password: "SecurePass123",
    passwordConfirmation: "SecurePass123"
  }) {
    id
    role
    status
    merchant {
      id
      businessName
      businessType
      status
    }
  }
}
```

fields.name: registerUser
fields.description: Register a new user

fields.name: rejectBankInfo
fields.description:
Reject bank information for KYC compliance.

## Authentication and Authorization
- Requires admin authentication with active status
- Only active admins can reject KYC components
- Admin must not be deleted

## Rejection Process
1. System validates admin credentials and permissions
2. Bank info status is updated to 'rejected'
3. Rejection reason is recorded for audit and compliance purposes
4. KYC application overall status may be affected
5. Operation is logged for audit and compliance purposes

## Example: Reject Bank Information
```graphql
mutation {
  rejectBankInfo(input: {
    bankInfoId: "bank_info_123",
    reason: "Bank account details cannot be verified"
  }) {
    success
    message
    kycApplication {
      id
      status
      bankInfoStatus
    }
  }
}
```

fields.name: suspendAdmin
fields.description:
Suspend an admin account in the system.

## Authentication and Authorization
- Requires admin authentication with active status
- Only admins can suspend other admins
- Admin performing the suspension must be in 'active' status
- Self-suspension is not allowed (an admin cannot suspend themselves)

## Suspension Process
1. System verifies admin credentials and permissions
2. Target admin account status is changed to 'suspended'
3. All active sessions for the suspended admin are invalidated
4. Operation is logged for audit and compliance purposes

## Security Implications
- Suspended admins immediately lose access to all admin functionality
- Any active JWT tokens for the suspended admin are invalidated
- API requests from suspended admins receive 403 Forbidden responses
- Account remains in the system but cannot perform any operations

## Suspension vs. Deletion
- Suspension is reversible (admin can be reactivated later)
- Account history and audit trail are preserved
- Preferable to deletion for compliance and security purposes

## Example: Suspend an Admin
```graphql
mutation {
  suspendAdmin(input: {
    adminId: "123"
  }) {
    success
    message
    admin {
      id
      firstName
      lastName
      email
      status
    }
    errors {
      field
      message
    }
  }
}
```

## Response Format
```json
{
  "data": {
    "suspendAdmin": {
      "success": true,
      "message": "Admin account suspended successfully",
      "admin": {
        "id": "123",
        "firstName": "John",
        "lastName": "Doe",
        "email": "admin@example.com",
        "status": "suspended"
      },
      "errors": null
    }
  }
}
```

## Error Cases
- Attempting to suspend a non-existent admin
- Attempting to suspend one's own admin account
- Insufficient permissions (non-admin attempting the operation)
- Admin attempting the suspension is not in active status

fields.name: transfer
updateBankInfo
updateCurrency
fields.description:
Update an existing currency's information (admin only).

This mutation allows administrators to modify currency details such as exchange rates,
status, country information, and other properties. Only users with 'admin' or 'super-admin'
roles can perform this operation.

## Access Control
- **Required Roles**: `admin`, `super-admin`
- **Authentication**: Required

## Use Cases
- Update exchange rates when market rates change
- Activate or deactivate currencies
- Modify country associations for a currency
- Update currency display information (name, symbol)
- Adjust precision for specific currencies

## Input Fields
All fields in the input are optional, allowing for partial updates:
- `code`: ISO 4217 currency code (e.g., 'USD', 'EUR')
- `name`: Full currency name (e.g., 'US Dollar')
- `symbol`: Currency symbol (e.g., '$', '')
- `precision`: Number of decimal places
- `exchangeRateUsd`: Current exchange rate against USD
- `countryCode`: Primary ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code
- `isActive`: Whether the currency is available for use
- `countryNames`: List of countries where currency is used

## Example Usage
```graphql
mutation UpdateCurrency {
  updateCurrency(
    currencyId: "7dbab425-107a-4fea-a46d-aa8c37c6b6ae"
    input: {
      exchangeRateUsd: 3750.50
      isActive: true
      countryNames: ["Uganda", "South Sudan"]
    }
  ) {
    id
    code
    name
    symbol
    precision
    exchangeRateUsd
    countryCode
    isActive
    countryNames
    updatedAt
  }
}

args.name: currencyId
args.description: The ID of the currency to update

fields.name: updateDeclarationAndCommitment
updateFinancialInfo
updateIdentityDocument
updatePersonalInfo
updatePoliticalExposure
updateRole
fields.description:
Update a user's role in the system.

## Authentication and Authorization
- Requires admin authentication with active status
- Only admins can change user roles
- Admin performing the action must be in 'active' status

## Role Change Process
1. System verifies admin credentials and permissions
2. User account role is updated to the specified role
3. Relevant profile associations are maintained or created as needed
4. Operation is logged for audit purposes

## Valid Role Changes
- User to Merchant: Requires additional merchant profile creation
- User to Admin: Grants administrative privileges
- Merchant to User: Merchant-specific data is preserved but inactive
- Admin to User: Administrative privileges are revoked

## Security Considerations
- Role changes significantly affect system permissions
- Changes are logged with the admin ID who made the change
- Notifications are sent to affected users
- Multi-factor authentication may be required for critical role changes

## Example: Update User to Admin Role
```graphql
mutation {
  updateRole(input: {
    userAccountId: "123",
    role: "admin"
  }) {
    success
    message
    userAccount {
      id
      role
      status
      admin {
        id
        firstName
        lastName
        email
      }
    }
    errors {
      field
      message
    }
  }
}
```

## Response Format
```json
{
  "data": {
    "updateRole": {
      "success": true,
      "message": "User role updated successfully to admin",
      "userAccount": {
        "id": "123",
        "role": "admin",
        "status": "active",
        "admin": {
          "id": "456",

          "firstName": "John",
          "lastName": "Doe",
          "email": "john@example.com"
        }
      },
      "errors": null
    }
  }
}
```

## Error Cases
- Attempting to update a non-existent user account
- Attempting to set an invalid role type
- Insufficient permissions (non-admin attempting the operation)
- Admin attempting the operation is not in active status

fields.name: updateUser

args.name: id
args.description: ID of the user to update

fields.name: updateWallet
verifyBankInfo
fields.description:
Verify bank information for KYC compliance.

## Authentication and Authorization
- Requires admin authentication with active status
- Only active admins can verify KYC components
- Admin must not be deleted

## Verification Process
1. System validates admin credentials and permissions
2. Bank information verification status is updated to specified status
3. System checks if all KYC components are now approved
4. If all components approved, KYC application status is automatically updated to 'complete'
5. Operation is logged for audit and compliance purposes

## Example: Verify Bank Information
```graphql
mutation {
  verifyBankInfo(bankInfoId: "bank_info_123") {
    success
    message
    kycApplication {
      id
      status
      bankInfoStatus
    }
  }
}
```

fields.name: verifyContactDetail
fields.description:
Verify contact details for KYC compliance.

## Authentication and Authorization
- Requires admin authentication with active status
- Only active admins can verify KYC components
- Admin must not be deleted

## Verification Process
1. System validates admin credentials and permissions
2. Contact detail verification status is updated to specified status
3. System checks if all KYC components are now approved
4. If all components approved, KYC application status is automatically updated to 'complete'
5. Operation is logged for audit and compliance purposes

## Example: Verify Contact Details
```graphql
mutation {
  verifyContactDetail(contactDetailId: "contact_detail_123") {
    success
    message
    kycApplication {
      id
      status
      contactDetailStatus
    }
  }
}
```

fields.name: verifyFinancialInfo
fields.description:
Verify financial information for KYC compliance.

## Authentication and Authorization
- Requires admin authentication with active status
- Only active admins can verify KYC components
- Admin must not be deleted

## Verification Process
1. System validates admin credentials and permissions
2. Financial information verification status is updated to specified status
3. System checks if all KYC components are now approved
4. If all components approved, KYC application status is automatically updated to 'complete'
5. Operation is logged for audit and compliance purposes

## Example: Verify Financial Information
```graphql
mutation {
  verifyFinancialInfo(financialInfoId: "yuhgvajshdvkjahd;lw1") {
    success
    message
    kycApplication {
      id
      status
      financialInfoStatus
    }
  }
}
```

fields.name: verifyIdentityDocument
fields.description:
Verify an identity document for KYC compliance.

## Authentication and Authorization
- Requires admin authentication with active status
- Only active admins can verify KYC components
- Admin must not be deleted

## Verification Process
1. System validates admin credentials and permissions
2. Identity document verification status is updated to specified status
3. System checks if all KYC components are now approved
4. If all components approved, KYC application status is automatically updated to 'complete'
5. Operation is logged for audit and compliance purposes

## Automatic KYC Completion
When this verification results in all KYC components being approved, the system automatically:
- Updates the KYC application status to 'complete'
- Returns an enhanced success message indicating completion
- Enables full wallet functionality for the user

## Example: Verify Identity Document
```graphql
mutation {
    verifyIdentityDocument(identityDocumentId: "identity_doc_123") {
    success
    message
    kycApplication {
      id
      status
      identityDocumentStatus
    }
    errors {
      field
      message
    }
  }
}
```

fields.name: verifyPersonalInfo
fields.description:
Verify personal information for KYC compliance.

## Authentication and Authorization
- Requires admin authentication with active status
- Only active admins can verify KYC components
- Admin must not be deleted

## Verification Process
1. System validates admin credentials and permissions
2. Personal information verification status is updated to specified status
3. System checks if all KYC components are now approved
4. If all components approved, KYC application status is automatically updated to 'complete'
5. Operation is logged for audit and compliance purposes
## Example: Verify Personal Information
```graphql
mutation {
  verifyPersonalInfo(personalInfoId: "yuhgvajshdvkjahd;lw1") {
    success
    message
    kycApplication {

    }
  }
}

## Verification Process

fields.name: walletToWalletTransfer
withdrawOrTransfer
fields.description:
Withdraw or transfer money from a wallet (mobile money or in-app transfer).

This mutation allows you to withdraw funds from a wallet to a mobile money account (e.g., M-Pesa, MTN MoMo, Orange, Airtel) or transfer to another wallet, depending on the provider and input.

## Usage
- Use for both mobile money withdrawals and in-app wallet transfers.
- Specify the wallet ID, currency code, amount, provider, and receiver phone number.
- The provider must be one of: `mtn_momo`, `m_pesa`, `orange`, `airtel`.
- The receiver phone number must be in international format (e.g., `+2547XXXXXXX` for Kenya).

## Input Example
```graphql
mutation {
  withdrawOrTransfer(input: {
    walletId: "abc123"
    currencyCode: "UGX"
    amount: 2000
    provider: m_pesa
    receiverPhone: "+254708374149"
    description: "Withdrawal to M-Pesa"
  }) {
    balance {
      availableBalance
      pendingBalance
      reservedBalance
    }
    transaction {
      id
      status
      reference
      provider
      amount
      insertedAt
    }
    success
    message
  }
}
```

## Output
- `balance`: The updated wallet balance after withdrawal/transfer.
- `transaction`: The withdrawal/transfer transaction details.
- `success`: Boolean indicating if the operation succeeded.
- `message`: User-friendly status or error message.

## Error Handling
- If the withdrawal fails, `success` will be `false` and `message` will contain the error reason.
- Common errors: insufficient funds, invalid phone number, provider unavailable, wallet frozen.

## Notes
- For in-app transfers, use the `transfer` or `walletToWalletTransfer` mutations.
- For mobile money, ensure the phone number matches the provider's requirements.
- All input and output fields are camelCase as per GraphQL best practices.

fields.name: me
fields.description:
Get the currently authenticated user's profile.

## Authentication Requirements
- Requires a valid JWT token in the Authorization header
- Works for all user roles (user, merchant, admin)

## Purpose and Usage
This query is a fundamental endpoint for client applications to:
1. Verify that authentication is valid
2. Retrieve current user profile information
3. Check account status and role
4. Access role-specific data (user, merchant, or admin profile)

## Recommended Implementation Pattern
- Call this query when your application initializes
- Use it to determine which UI elements to show based on role
- Check account status to handle inactive/suspended accounts
- Cache the response but refresh periodically

## Response Structure
- `id`: Unique identifier for the user account
- `role`: User role (user, merchant, or admin)
- `status`: Account status (active, inactive, pending, suspended)
- Role-specific profile data in the appropriate nested object:
  - `user`: For regular user accounts
  - `merchant`: For merchant accounts
  - `admin`: For admin accounts

## Common Use Cases
1. **Session Verification**: Check if the user's token is still valid
2. **Profile Display**: Show user information in profile screens
3. **Role-Based UI**: Conditionally show UI elements based on role
4. **Status Handling**: Redirect/notify based on account status

## Error Handling
- 401 Unauthorized: Invalid or expired token
- 403 Forbidden: Valid token but account is suspended/inactive

## Example: Basic Profile Query
```graphql
query {
  me {
    id
    role
    status
    user {
      firstName
      lastName
      email
      phone
      country
    }
  }
}
```

## Example: Merchant Profile Query
```graphql
query {
  me {
    id
    role
    status
    merchant {
      businessName
      businessType
      businessWebsite
      businessDescription
      status
    }
  }
}
```

## Example: Admin Profile Query
```graphql
query {
  me {
    id
    role
    status
    admin {
      firstName
      lastName
      email
      status
    }
  }
}
```

fields.name: users
fields.description:
Retrieves a paginated, sorted, and filtered list of users.

This query is only accessible to users with 'admin', 'super-admin', or 'manager' roles.
It supports powerful filtering capabilities, including search across multiple fields,
date range filtering, and exact matches on specific fields like status or country.

**Example Usage:**
```graphql
query GetUsersList {
  users(page: 1, perPage: 10, sortBy: "insertedAt", sortDirection: "desc", search: "john", filters: {status: "active"}) {
    entries {
      id
      firstName
      email
      status
    }
    pageNumber
    pageSize
    totalEntries
    totalPages
  }
}
```

args.name: page
args.description: The page number to fetch (defaults to 1).

args.name: perPage
args.description: The number of items per page (defaults to 20).

args.name: search
args.description: A search term to filter users by name, email, or phone.

args.name: toDate
args.description: End of the date range for filtering by `inserted_at` (inclusive).

types.name: Session
types.description:
Represents an authenticated user session with token and account information.

## Fields
- `token`: JWT authentication token containing expiry and signature details
- `user_account`: The authenticated user's account information
- Associated profile based on role: `user`, `merchant`, or `admin`

## Token Usage
The returned token must be included in the Authorization header of subsequent
API requests using the Bearer token format: `Authorization: Bearer {token}`.

## Session Lifecycle
- Token has a default validity of 24 hours
- Token becomes invalid upon logout
- User data is accessible based on role permissions

## Security Considerations
- Store tokens securely on client devices
- For web applications, consider HttpOnly cookies with secure and SameSite flags
- For mobile applications, use secure storage mechanisms
- Always validate token expiry before use

## Example Response Structure
```json
{
  "token": {
    "value": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...",
    "expiry": "2023-08-15T12:00:00Z"
  },
  "userAccount": {
    "id": "1",
    "role": "user",
    "status": "active"
  },
  "user": {
    "firstName": "John",
    "lastName": "Doe",
    "email": "user@example.com"
  }
}
```

types.name: Token
types.description:
Authentication tokens for the API.

## Token Types
- `access_token`: The primary JWT token used for authentication
- `refresh_token`: Long-lived token used to obtain new access tokens without re-authentication

## Token Lifecycle
- Access tokens typically expire after 24 hours
- Refresh tokens typically expire after 30 days
- Use the refresh_token mutation to get a new access token when it expires

## Security Guidelines
- Store tokens securely on client devices
- Never store tokens in client-side storage like localStorage in browsers
- For web applications: Use HttpOnly cookies with secure and SameSite flags
- For mobile applications: Use secure storage mechanisms like Keychain (iOS) or KeyStore (Android)

## Token Format
The access_token is a JWT (JSON Web Token) with three parts:
- Header (algorithm and token type)
- Payload (claims about the user)
- Signature (to verify the token hasn't been tampered with)

## Example Usage in Headers
```
Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...
```

## Claims in the Access Token
- `sub`: Subject (user ID)
- `role`: User role (user, admin, merchant)
- `iat`: Issued at (timestamp)
- `exp`: Expiration time (timestamp)
- `iss`: Issuer (KpPay)

fields.name: accessToken
fields.description: JWT token for API authentication (valid for 24 hours)

fields.name: refreshToken
fields.description: Long-lived token used to obtain new access tokens

types.name: TokenExpiration
types.description:
Token expiration information for client-side token management.

## Fields
- `expires_at`: ISO8601 formatted date and time when the token will expire
- `expires_in_seconds`: Number of seconds until token expiration

## Client-Side Token Management
Use this information to:
1. Proactively refresh tokens before they expire
2. Display session timeout warnings to users
3. Implement countdown timers for session expiration

## Best Practices
- Refresh tokens when 75-90% of their lifetime has elapsed
- For critical operations, consider re-authentication regardless of token validity
- Implement graceful session expiration handling in your UI

## Example Response
```json
{
  "data": {
    "getTokenExpiration": {
      "expiresAt": "2023-08-15T12:00:00Z",
      "expiresInSeconds": 3600
    }
  }
}
```

fields.name: expiresAt
fields.description: ISO8601 formatted expiration date and time

fields.name: expiresInSeconds
fields.description: Number of seconds until the token expires

types.name: UserAccount
types.description:
A user account representing the authentication entity in the system.

This type connects the authentication system with role-specific profiles (user, admin, merchant).
It contains authentication-related data like sign-in history and account status.

The actual profile data is accessed through the role-specific associations:
- `user`: Regular user profile data (if role is "user")
- `admin`: Administrator profile data (if role is "admin")
- `merchant`: Merchant profile data (if role is "merchant")

Status values:
- "active": Account is fully functional
- "inactive": Account is temporarily disabled
- "locked": Account is locked due to security concerns
- "pending": Account is awaiting approval or verification

types.name: UserRoleInput
types.description:
Input for updating a user's role in the system.

## Fields
- `user_account_id`: The unique identifier of the user account to update
- `role`: The new role to assign (must be one of: "user", "admin", or "merchant")

## Valid Role Values
- "user": Standard user account with basic permissions
- "admin": Administrator with elevated system privileges
- "merchant": Business account with merchant-specific features

## Role Change Implications
- When changing to "merchant": Additional merchant profile data may be required
- When changing to "admin": User gains access to administrative functions
- When downgrading from "admin": User loses administrative privileges

## Security Considerations
- Role changes significantly affect system permissions
- Only active admins can change user roles
- All role changes are logged for audit purposes

## Example
```graphql
mutation {
  updateRole(input: {
    userAccountId: "123",
    role: "admin"
  }) {
    success
    message
    userAccount {
      id
      role
    }
  }
}
```

inputFields.name: role
inputFields.description: New role to assign (user, admin, or merchant)

Input for updating an existing user's profile information.

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name, description and optional `specifiedByUrl`, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields`, `interfaces`, and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FIELD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: VARIABLE_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a variable definition.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object type definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object type definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.

directives.name: include
directives.description: Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true.

directives.name: skip
directives.description: Directs the executor to skip this field or fragment when the `if` argument is true.

directives.name: deprecated
directives.description: Marks an element of a GraphQL schema as no longer supported.

args.name: reason
args.description: Explains why this element was deprecated, usually also including a suggestion for how to access supported similar data. Formatted using the Markdown syntax, as specified by [CommonMark](https://commonmark.org/).

directives.name: specifiedBy
directives.description: Exposes a URL that specifies the behaviour of this scalar.

args.name: url
args.description: The URL that specifies the behaviour of this scalar.

directives.name: client
directives.description: Direct the client to resolve this field locally, either from the cache or local resolvers.

args.name: always
args.description:
When true, the client will never use the cache for this value. See
https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/essentials/local-state/#forcing-resolvers-with-clientalways-true

directives.name: export
directives.description:
Export this locally resolved field as a variable to be used in the remainder of this query. See
https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/essentials/local-state/#using-client-fields-as-variables

args.name: as
args.description: The variable name to export this field as.

directives.name: connection
directives.description:
Specify a custom store key for this result. See
https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/advanced/caching/#the-connection-directive

args.name: filter
args.description: An array of query argument names to include in the generated custom store key.
